response_template:
Hello {student_name},

Thanks for reaching out! The registration period for {term} closes on {registration_deadline}. You can continue to add classes until 11:59 p.m. on that date through the student portal. If you need to make changes afterward, please submit an Add/Drop form and obtain approval from your academic advisor.

Here are a few tips to stay on track:
• Double-check your degree audit to ensure the courses fit your academic plan.
• Resolve any holds before the deadline so you do not lose access.
• If you run into registration errors, send us a screenshot and we will be glad to help.

Let us know if you have additional questions!

Best regards,
Academic Advising Team
follow_up_questions: Are you planning to take the course for credit or audit?
Do you have any registration holds on your account?

Hello {student_name},

We would be glad to meet with you! Advising appointments can be scheduled online through the Navigate Student app or by visiting the advising portal on the university website. You will see available 30-minute meeting times for your assigned advisor over the next two weeks.

If you do not see a time that works for you, reply with a few windows of availability and we will follow up with alternatives. Virtual meetings via Zoom are also available upon request.

Talk soon,
Academic Advising Team

How do I drop class with W?
How do I late withdrawal options?
How do I withdraw from a course due to personal reasons?
How do I withdraw from course?
How do I withdrawal paperwork?
response_template:
Hello {student_name},

To withdraw from a course after the add/drop period, please submit the Course Withdrawal form located in the Records and Registration section of the student portal. The form requires signatures from both you and the course instructor. Once approved, the Registrar will record a grade of 'W'.

Key reminders:
• The withdrawal deadline for {term} is {withdrawal_deadline}.
• Withdrawing may impact your financial aid or progress toward graduation.
• International students should consult with the Office of Global Engagement before submitting the form.

Please let us know if you would like to talk through the decision or explore alternative options.

Sincerely,
Academic Advising Team
follow_up_questions: Have you spoken with your course instructor about the withdrawal?
Would you like to review how this might impact your financial aid?

How do I i’d like to switch to an IEOR major?
How do I major declaration form submission?
How do I change my major before junior year?
response_template:
Hello {student_name},

Thanks for reaching out! To change or declare a major, you will first need to obtain permission by an advisor in your new department. Afterward, you will need to complete the Major/Minor Declaration/Change form, available here: {major_minor_declaration_form}. The form must be submitted to Kelly Katsigiris, the Academic & Student Affairs for IEOR undergraduate students. She will read and sign the form, and then she will send it to your CSA advisor. Before you submit the form, we highly recommend you review the program requirements in the Columbia Engineering Bulletin to ensure it’s a good fit, and check to see if any of the courses you’ve taken count towards the new major. We would be happy to meet to discuss this decision and help you create an updated academic plan. Let us know what you decide! Best regards, Academic Advising Team
follow_up_questions: Have you checked if the classes you’ve taken count towards your new major?

utterances: Does this class count towards my elective requirements?

Do I need to take management electives?

Need list of approved technical electives?
What management electives can I pick?
How many elective credits are required?
response_template:
Hello {student_name},

Great question! Choosing the right electives is a key part of tailoring your degree to your interests. The approved lists for both management and technical electives can be found on the IEOR Department website in the Undergraduate Curriculum page. The official list is available at {link_to_elective_list}. 

Here's a quick guide:
• **Technical Electives:** These are typically upper-level (3000-level and above) courses in IEOR or a related technical field (e.g. Computer Science, Math, Economics) designed to deepen your expertise. All IEOR majors are required to take at least six credits of IEOR technical electives, and the total number of technical credits required varies by major. 
• **Management Electives:** These courses cover topics like project management, finance, or marketing and are intended to provide you with valuable business context for your technical skills. The number of management credits required also varies by major. 

We highly recommend cross-referencing the approved list with your program plan to confirm how many credits you need. 

Best regards,
Academic Advising Team
follow_up_questions: Would you like to meet to discuss which electives align best with your interests and career goals?

subject: Petitioning Electives
utterances: Can I petition for this class to count?

Can I petition for this class to count as a management elective?
I think this course aligns with IEOR themes..
How do I submit an elective petition?
Course approval request form question..
How do I course approval request form question?
response_template:
Hello {student_name},

Thanks for reaching out! Enrollment into a course which is not pre-approved for your program requires approval from your faculty advisor & the IEOR Department. To enroll in a course not pre-approved by the IEOR department, proceed with the following steps:

1. Submit Your Request: Submit the IEOR BS Course Approval Request Form to seek approval from the IEOR Department: {ieor_course_approval_request_form}.
2. IEOR Department Approval: Please allow the Department 1 business week to review your course request. We may follow-up if additional information is required.

Note, all doctoral level courses require approval (IEOR6000-8000). If you are approved by your faculty advisor for a doctoral course, register for the course in SSOL via the waitlist before you submit this form. The IEOR Department will review your request within 1 business week (2 business days during add/drop) and admit you into the course from the waitlist.

Reminder: Courses from SPS / QMSS classes are not approved.
Reminder: Programming courses from CBS are not approved.

We would be happy to meet with you to discuss your program plan and if this course makes sense with your professional interests.

Best regards,
Academic Advising Team
follow_up_questions: Would you like to meet to discuss your other electives and program plan?
Have you met with your faculty advisor to discuss this course?

subject: Applying to Graduate
utterances: How do I apply for graduation?
Am I on track to graduate?
When is the graduation application deadline?
I’d like to get my program plan approved..
Where is the degree application form?
Need help submitting graduation paperwork?
How do I i’d like to get my program plan approved?
response_template:
Hello {student_name},

Congratulations on reaching your final year! To be approved for graduation, you must first fill out the program plan for your major. These can be found on the IEOR Undergraduate Advising and Resources page, available here: {link_to_undergrad_advising}. Afterward, please send your finished plan to the head of IEOR Undergraduate Advising Kelly Katsigiris so she can sign off on your program plan. After you receive Kelly’s signature, you can send the program plan to the Center for Student Advising to process. 

Once all of this is cleared, you must submit the degree application form in Vergil. The deadline to apply for {term} graduation is {graduation_application_deadline}.

Please be sure to review your program plan and degree audit on Stellic to confirm that all requirements will be met by the end of the term. If you see any discrepancies or have questions about remaining requirements, please schedule a meeting with us as soon as possible for a final review.

We look forward to celebrating with you!

Sincerely,
Academic Advising Team
follow_up_questions: Have you filled out your program plan?

subject: Information about MS Express
utterances: Where can I find information about MS Express?
How can I apply for MS Express?
When is the MS Express application deadline?
Which of my classes might count towards MS Express?
Does MS Express require GRE?
How competitive is MS Express?
response_template:
Hello {student_name},

We’re excited to hear that you are considering a graduate education at Columbia Engineering! MS Express is a simplified process of applying to Columbia Engineering's Master of Science programs available to currently enrolled seniors at Columbia Engineering and young alumni (students who graduated from Columbia Engineering within the last three years). Columbia Engineering undergraduates and young alumni may apply to any engineering MS program using the express application. A minimum cumulative 3.3 GPA is required. 

You can apply through MS Express here: {MS_express_link}. The application requires official transcripts, a personal statement, a resume or CV, and contact information for three references. There is no application fee. 

We would be happy to meet with you if you have further questions about how your undergraduate courses might count towards an MS degree. 

Best regards, 
Academic Advising Team
follow_up_questions: Would you like to meet to discuss which undergraduate classes might count towards an MS degree?

subject: Information about IEOR Advanced Track
utterances: Where can I find information about the advanced track?
How can I apply for the advanced track?
What is the difference between the regular IEOR core and the advanced track?
Should I do the advanced track?
Advanced track GPA requirement..
Advanced track application deadline..
How do I advanced track GPA requirement?
How do I advanced track application deadline?
response_template:
Hello {student_name},

The Undergraduate Advanced Track (UAT) is designed for advanced undergraduate students with the desire to pursue further education after graduation. Students with a minimum cumulative GPA of 3.4 and faculty approval have the opportunity to participate. Students are invited to apply to the track upon completing their sophomore year. The application can be accessed here: {link_to_uat_app}. Students successfully completing the requirements of the undergraduate advanced track will receive recognition on their academic record.

UAT students are required to take IEOR E3700: Research Immersion in OR and Data Analytics, IEOR E3900: Undergrad Research or Project, and six Advanced Course credits from an approved list of courses. You can find more information about coursework in the Columbia Engineering Bulletin, available here: {link_to_uat}.

Best regards, 
Academic Advising Team
follow_up_questions: Would you like to meet to discuss how the Undergraduate Advanced Track might further your career and academic goals?

response_template:
Hello {student_name},

All Columbia Engineering Undergraduate students declare their major in October of their second year. Major declaration for Columbia Engineering sophomores is open this fall from {start_date} to {end_date}. For more information on the steps to declare your major, please visit the Major Declaration page on the Center for Student Advising website, available here: {link_to_csa_declaration}. 

The IEOR department offers five undergraduate majors: Industrial Engineering, Operations Research, Operations Research: Analytics, Operations Research: Engineering Management Systems, and Operations Research: Financial Engineering. Each major requires three concentration requirements, as well as varying numbers of technical and management elective credits. For information about the curricular requirements for each major, please visit the Undergraduate Curriculum page on the IEOR department website, available here: {link_to_undergrad_curriculum}.

We would be happy to meet with you to discuss the specific major requirements and to devise an IEOR program plan.

Best regards,
Academic Advising Team
follow_up_questions: Which IEOR majors are you considering?

response_template:
Hello {student_name},

We’re happy to hear that you are considering studying abroad! Columbia Engineering undergraduates typically study abroad during the spring semester of their sophomore year. Alternatively, you might choose to study abroad during the summer through a Columbia-sponsored program. During certain study abroad programs, students are able to fulfill some of their engineering prerequisite requirements and/or humanities core requirements. For more information about available programs, please visit the Programs page on the Center for Undergraduate Engagement website, available here: {study_abroad_opportunities}.

We would be happy to meet with you to discuss which programs might be best suited for your academic and professional interests, as well as to talk about which requirements can be fulfilled abroad.

Warm regards,
Academic Advising Team

subject: Information about Barnard 4+1
utterances: What are the requirements for the Barnard 4+1 Pathway in IEOR?
When is the Barnard 4+1 application due?
Where can I learn more about the Barnard 4+1 pathway?
What are the prerequisites to apply for the Barnard 4+1 in IEOR?
Which of my classes count towards an MS degree if I do the Barnard 4+1 program?
How will my credits transfer to an MS degree through Barnard 4+1?
Does Barnard 4+1 require recommendation letters?
Minimum GPA for the Barnard pathway..
How do I minimum GPA for the Barnard pathway?
response_template:
Hello {student_name},

We’re happy to hear that you are considering Columbia Engineering for your graduate education! Barnard College offers several pathways in conjunction with Columbia Engineering, including a BA/MS in Industrial Engineering and Operations Research. For all of the 4+1 pathways, students must maintain a GPA at or above 3.5 and apply by February 15 of their junior year. Applications for the Engineering 4+1 Pathways are submitted directly to Columbia Engineering. No standardized test scores are required for 4+1 applicants.

For the BS/MS in Industrial Engineering and Operations Research, students must complete the following prerequisites by the end of their fall semester of their junior year: Multivariable Calculus for Engineering and Applied Science (or Calculus III), Linear Algebra, Introduction to Probability & Statistics, and Foundations of Data Science. The majors with requirements that most closely track with these prerequisites are Economics & Math and Economics & Statistics. Other majors may apply to the pathway but students should discuss their plans with the Barnard faculty lead to assess their readiness for masters level engineering classes and the strength of their application. Successful applicants have extensive quantitative course work through their major or minor. 

For more information, please visit the 4+1 Pathways page on the Barnard website, available here: {barnard_four_plus_one}. We would be happy to meet with you to discuss how your undergraduate coursework might translate to the MS degree.

Best regards,
Academic Advising Team
follow_up_questions: Are there specific programs that you are considering?
Have you compiled all of your application materials?

subject: Information about 3+2 Combined Plan Program
utterances: How does the 3+2 program work?
What is the Combined Plan program?
3+2 combined plan information
3+2 Deadline
Requirements for 3+2 admission
Can I do 3+2 at Columbia Engineering?
Combined Plan application process
How do I apply to the 3+2 program?
What are the prerequisites for Combined Plan?
3+2 program from liberal arts college
Transfer to Columbia Engineering through 3+2
response_template:
Hello {student_name},

Thank you for your interest in the Combined Plan Program (also known as the 3+2 Program)! This program allows students from affiliated liberal arts colleges to earn two degrees: a Bachelor of Arts from their home institution and a Bachelor of Science from Columbia Engineering.

Here's how the program works:
• Students typically spend three years at their home institution completing liberal arts requirements and pre-engineering coursework.
• Students then transfer to Columbia Engineering for two years to complete their engineering degree.
• Upon completion, students receive both a BA from their original college and a BS from Columbia.

Key requirements:
• Strong academic record with a recommended GPA of 3.3 or higher
• Completion of prerequisite courses in mathematics (through differential equations), physics, chemistry, and computer science
• Recommendation from your home institution's Combined Plan advisor
• Application typically submitted during the fall of your third year

For detailed information about prerequisites, affiliated colleges, and application deadlines, please visit the Combined Plan page on the Columbia Engineering website: {combined_plan_link}

We would be happy to meet with you to discuss whether the Combined Plan is a good fit for your academic goals.

Best regards,
Academic Advising Team
follow_up_questions: Which affiliated college are you currently attending?
Have you completed the prerequisite math and science courses?
Which engineering major are you considering at Columbia?
